questions.text: A 40-year-old woman reports experiencing recurrent headaches that last between 6 and 48 hours. She often feels fatigued and has mood changes before the headaches begin. According to the International Headache Society's criteria, which features are essential for diagnosing her condition as migraine?

options.label: B
options.text: Unilateral pain with photophobia without nausea

options.label: D
options.text: Bilateral pain with photophobia and nausea

questions.correct_answer: C. Unilateral throbbing pain with phonophobia
questions.explanation:
Clinical Features of Migraine

Premonitory (Prodromal) Phase
  • Neck discomfort
  • Cognitive impairment (brain “fog”)
  • Mood changes
  • Fatigue
  • Yawning/sleepiness
  • Increased urination and thirst
  • Food cravings

Aura
  • Neurologic disturbances (e.g., visual disturbances like scintillating scotoma)
  • Due to Cerebral vasoconstriction. Therefore prevention is by Vasodilators.

Headache Phase
  • Pain
  • Nausea/vomiting
  • Sensory sensitivities:
    • Photophobia (sensitivity to light)
    • Phonophobia (sensitivity to sound)
    • Osmophobia (sensitivity to smells)
    • Allodynia (pain from non-painful stimuli)
    • Vertigo
  • Due to cerebral vasodilation. So treatment is Vasoconstrictors

Postdrome
  • Tiredness
  • Weariness
  • Impaired concentration

Simplified Diagnostic Criteria for Migraine by International Headache Society

Repeated attacks of headache lasting 4–72h in patients with a normal physical examination, no other reasonable cause for the headache, and:

At least 2 of the following features:

Plus at least 1 of the following features:
  • Unilateral pain
  • Throbbing pain
  • Aggravation by movement
  • Moderate or severe intensity
  • Nausea/vomiting
  • Photophobia and phonophobia

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a 9-month history of frequent headaches occurring at least 3 times per week. She describes the pain as a dull, bilateral ache that feels like a tight band around her head. The headaches are often accompanied by neck tension, stress, and fatigue. She reports difficulty concentrating due to the pain, and her sleep has been disrupted. The patient is looking for a long-term solution to manage her condition. Which of the following is the most appropriate first-line treatment for this patient's condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Amitriptyline, starting at 20 mg daily, with gradual increases as needed.

options.label: B
options.text: Combination of Ibuprofen 400 mg plus acetaminophen 1000 mg.

options.label: C
options.text: Aspirin and Botulinum toxin type A

options.label: D
options.text: Combination of massage therapy and acupuncture

questions.correct_answer: A. Amitriptyline, starting at 20 mg daily, with gradual increases as needed.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents with recurrent, sharp, electric shock-like pain on the right side of her face, affecting her jaw and cheek. The pain is triggered by light touch, such as brushing her teeth or shaving. She reports these episodes happening multiple times a day and lasting only a few seconds. Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding her condition?

options.label: A
options.text: The most likely diagnosis is glossopharyngeal neuralgia, as the pain is localized to the jaw and oral cavity and is triggered by chewing.

options.label: B
options.text: Most commonly caused by vascular compression of the trigeminal nerve, often by the superior cerebellar artery.

options.label: C
options.text: The primary treatment is surgical decompression of the glossopharyngeal nerve.

options.label: D
options.text: This patient's condition is most likely to involve the ophthalmic branch (V1) of the trigeminal nerve.

questions.correct_answer: B. Most commonly caused by vascular compression of the trigeminal nerve, often by the superior cerebellar artery.
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Trigeminal Neuralgia

Glossopharyngeal Neuralgia

About
  • Also known as "tic douloureux," is a chronic neurological condition marked by recurrent, brief episodes of electric shock-like facial pain.
  • Usually affects one side of the face and commonly involves the maxillary (V2) and mandibular (V3) branches of the trigeminal nerve.
  • Pain episodes are triggered by stimuli like touch, chewing, or exposure to cold air.
  • A rare pain syndrome affecting the sensory distribution of the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX).
  • Characterized by brief, sharp, unilateral pain in areas like the jaw angle, ear, tonsillar fossa, and base of the tongue.
  • Pain episodes are triggered by coughing, talking, or swallowing. (Option A ruled out)

Etiopathogenesis
  • Caused mainly by vascular compression of the trigeminal nerve root, ofte,pn by the superior cerebellar artery.
  • Other causes include space-occupying lesions (e.g., tumors), multiple sclerosis, or other vascular abnormalities.
  • Compression leads to demyelination of the nerve, resulting in abnormal transmission of impulses, causing pain.
  • Idiopathic (unknown cause) or secondary to specific conditions:
  • Vascular compression, especially near the nerve root.
  • Demyelinating diseases (e.g., multiple sclerosis), infections, and autoimmune conditions (e.g., Sjögren's disease).
  • Intracranial tumors (medullary tumors, CP angle tumors).
  • Anatomical anomalies (Eagle syndrome).
  • Rarely linked with oropharyngeal cancers (e.g., tongue carcinoma).

Clinical Features
  • Pain is typically unilateral, sharp, and brief, often described as "electric shock-like."
  • Triggers include light touch to specific facial areas ("trigger zones") and routine activities like brushing teeth or shaving.
  • Pain episodes can occur multiple times per day, sometimes with a refractory period following each episode.
  • V1 involvement (rare) may present with autonomic symptoms like tearing and rhinorrhea. (Option D ruled out)
  • Intense, episodic, sharp pain lasting seconds to minutes.
  • Pain is unilateral, often affecting the ear, tongue base, and tonsillar fossa.
  • Relapsing-remitting pain pattern, may lead to weight loss due to difficulty eating.
  • Occasionally, pain is associated with bradycardia, asystole, or syncope.

Diagnosis
  • Diagnosis is often clinical, supported by MRI or MRA to rule out secondary causes or vascular compression.
  • High-resolution MRI (e.g., FIESTA sequencing) helps visualize nerve compression.
  • Diagnosis based on the International Classification of Headache Disorders criteria includes unilateral pain lasting seconds to minutes, triggered by innocuous stimuli, and of severe intensity.
  • Clinical diagnosis with history and exam.
  • Imaging:
  • MRI: Preferred to identify nerve compression by blood vessels or tumors.
  • MRA: To detect vascular compression.
  • CT and X-ray: Useful for detecting an elongated or calcified styloid process in Eagle syndrome.
  • Cardiac evaluation for syncopal cases: Echocardiogram and Holter monitoring.

Treatment
  • Pharmacologic Therapy:
    • First-line: Carbamazepine (FDA-approved) or oxcarbazepine; both may cause dizziness, hyponatremia, and other side effects. (Option C ruled out)
    • Second-line: Gabapentin, clonazepam, lamotrigine, and baclofen; used if first-line agents are ineffective.
  • Surgical Therapy:
    • Microvascular decompression: Effective in >90% of cases; involves craniotomy and vessel decompression.
    • Rhizotomy: Ablative procedures like thermocoagulation or chemical injection of the trigeminal nerve for pain relief.
    • Peripheral neurectomy: Performed on trigeminal branches in remote areas; moderate success with some recurrence.
  • Other Therapies:
    • Botulinum toxin injections: Provides relief in cases refractory to medications.
    • Deep brain stimulation: Used as a last-resort option in refractory cases, with limited evidence of effectiveness.
  • Medications: Carbamazepine or oxcarbazepine are first-line; other options include gabapentin, duloxetine, and pregabalin.
  • Nerve Blocks: Glossopharyngeal nerve block with anesthetics or radiofrequency ablation for persistent pain.
  • Surgery: Microvascular decompression is the main surgery for vascular compression; other procedures include rhizotomy or stylectomy for Eagle syndrome.

questions.text: Match the following: 1. Naratriptan a) 5-HT1F Agonist 2. Lasmiditan b) Dopamine Receptor Antagonist 3. Rimegepant c) 5-HT1B/1D Agonist 4. Prochlorperazine d) CGRP Receptor Antagonist

A 56-year-old male presents to the emergency department following a severe head injury. On examination, he shows signs of increasing intracranial pressure, including altered consciousness and anisocoria (unequal pupil size). His CT scan reveals significant brain swelling and herniation. The medical team suspects a specific type of brain herniation. Which of the following types of brain herniation is most likely responsible for the patient’s altered pupillary response?
questions.explanation:
Types of Brain Herniation

Subfalcine Herniation
  • The cingulate gyrus moves beneath the anterior falx.
  • Leads to infarction in the anterior cerebral artery territory.
  • Causes lower limb weakness due to infarction of motor areas and compression of vessels. (Option A ruled out)

Transalar/ Transsphenoidal Herniation
  • Descending: Compression of the middle cerebral artery by the sphenoid ridge causes infarction.
  • Ascending: Compression of the internal carotid artery causes infarction in the anterior and middle cerebral arteries. (Option B ruled out)

Transtentorial Uncal Herniation
  • Compression of the 3rd nerve causes pupil changes (constriction followed by dilation).
  • Can lead to hydrocephalus, temporal/occipital lobe infarction, and ipsilateral motor deficits (Kernohan’s notch).

Central Herniation (Descending and Ascending)
  • Descending: Brainstem compression causes Duret hemorrhages and Cushing triad (hypertension, bradycardia, irregular respirations).
  • Ascending: Compression of the posterior cerebral or superior cerebellar arteries.

Cerebellar Tonsillar Herniation
  • Cerebellar tonsils move through the foramen magnum.
  • Compresses the brainstem and upper cervical cord, leading to life-threatening conditions.
  • Leads to ischemia of brainstem, tonsils, and lower cerebellum. (Option D ruled out)

Transcalvarial Herniation
  • Occurs due to calvarial defects (e.g., after hemicraniectomy).
  • Brain tissue herniates through the skull defect, potentially causing hemorrhagic infarction.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a history of recurrent headaches. After a thorough evaluation, he is diagnosed with a headache that has a stinging character and characterized by the following features: Duration: 5-240 seconds Attacks: 3-200 attacks per day. Which of the following treatments is most appropriate for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Cluster Headache

SUNCT

Duration of Attacks

15-180 minutes

5-240 seconds

Frequency of Attacks

1-8 attacks per day

3-200 attacks per day

Pain Quality

Severe, unilateral, often described as stabbing or boring

Sharp, unilateral, often described as stinging

Associated Symptoms

Lacrimation, nasal congestion, ptosis, miosis

Conjunctival injection, tearing

Circadian Pattern

Often occurs at the same time daily

No specific circadian pattern

Demographics

More common in males, typically age > 30

Can occur in both genders, usually age > 40

Triggers

Alcohol, certain foods, changes in sleep patterns

Stress, physical exertion, not well-defined triggers

First-line Treatment

High-flow oxygen, triptans (e.g., Sumatriptan)

IV Lidocaine

questions.text: A 70-year-old female presents with a 3-month history of new-onset headaches, scalp tenderness, and jaw claudication. She also reports significant fatigue and unintentional weight loss. Laboratory studies reveal an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP). What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Refer for imaging studies of the carotid arteries

questions.text: Match the variants of Migraine in Column A with their characteristic clinical features in Column B: Column A Column B 1. Ophthalmoplegic Migraine A. Associated with blindness and scintillating scotomas 2. Cluster Headaches B. Retro-orbital pain in males 3. Retinal Migraine C. Associated with occulomotor palsy 4. Familial Hemiplegic Migraine D. Presents with hemiplegia and can be confused with stroke E. Diagnosis often involves neuroimaging to rule out cerebrovascular accidents
questions.explanation:
Ophthalmoplegic Migraine
  • Ophthalmoplegic migraine can present with neurological deficits, such as third nerve palsy, which may include symptoms like ptosis and squinting.
  • It typically causes severe pain that can lead to vision impairment

Cluster Headaches
  • Cluster headaches are known for their unilateral, severe pain typically located around the eye, often described as retro-orbital pain.
  • They are more common in males and can be associated with other symptoms such as nasal congestion and watering of the eyes.

Retinal Migraine
  • Associated with transient vision loss or blindness due to vasospasm of the retinal arteries.
  • Symptoms such as scintillating scotomas are also present.

Familial Hemiplegic Migraine
  • Rare type of migraine that includes hemiplegia (temporary paralysis on one side of the body) as a symptom.
  • Because of this, it can easily be confused with a stroke.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with a history of chronic migraines visits his physician to discuss treatment options. He is interested in triptans but has some health concerns that he wants to clarify. Which of the following is NOT a contraindication for triptans based on the provided information?

A 28-year-old woman completes the MIDAS questionnaire during her follow-up for chronic migraines. Her headaches have significantly impacted her work and social life. What is the primary purpose of the MIDAS assessment?

options.label: A
options.text: To determine the specific medication needed for treatment.

options.label: B
options.text: To assess the frequency of headache attacks.

options.label: C
options.text: To evaluate headache-related disability and its impact on daily activities.

options.label: D
options.text: To classify the type of headache.

questions.correct_answer: C. To evaluate headache-related disability and its impact on daily activities.
questions.explanation:
MIDAS Questionnaire

Instructions

Please answer the following questions about all the headaches you have had over the last 3 months.

Select your answer in the box next to each question. Select zero if you did not have the activity in the last 3 months. Please take the complete form to your healthcare professional.

Questions
  1. On how many days in the last 3 months did you miss work or school because of your headaches?
  2. How many days in the last 3 months was your productivity at work or school reduced by half or more because of your headaches (do not include days you counted in question 1 where you missed work or school)?
  3. How many days in the last 3 months have you not done household work because of your headaches?
  4. How many days in the last 3 months was your productivity in household work reduced by half or more because of your headaches (do not include days you counted in question 3 where you did not do household work)?
  5. On how many days in the last 3 months did you miss family, social, or leisure activities because of your headaches?

What your Physician will need to know about your headaches:
  1. How many days in the last 3 months did you have a headache? (If a headache lasted more than one day, count each day.)
  2. On a scale of 0–10, on average how painful were these headaches? (Where 0 = no pain at all, and 10 = pain as bad as it can be.)

Grading

Total MIDAS scores categorize migraine-related disability into four grades:

  • Grade I: Little or no disability (0–5)
  • Grade II: Mild disability (6–10)
  • Grade III: Moderate disability (11–20)
  • Grade IV: Severe disability (≥ 21)

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to her doctor with a history of frequent migraines. She reports experiencing about five migraine attacks per month, which have not responded well to over-the-counter pain relievers. The attacks last between 24 and 48 hours and are accompanied by nausea and sensitivity to light and sound. Her doctor discusses the possibility of preventive treatment options. Based on her symptoms and frequency of attacks, which of the following preventive treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Treatment of Acute Migraine

Prevention of Migraine
  • Pharmacologic Options:
    • Simple Analgesics: Acetaminophen, aspirin, caffeine. (Option A ruled out)
    • NSAIDs: Naproxen, ibuprofen, tolfenamic acid, diclofenac.
    • Triptans (5-HT1B/1D Agonists): Sumatriptan, rizatriptan, naratriptan, eletriptan, frovatriptan, zolmitriptan. (Option C ruled out)
    • Gepants (CGRP Receptor Antagonists): Rimegepant, ubrogepant. (Option D ruled out)
    • Ditans (5-HT1F Agonists): Lasmiditan.
    • Dopamine Receptor Antagonists: Metoclopramide, prochlorperazine.
    • Other Options: Combination medications (e.g., acetaminophen, dichloralphenazone, isometheptene), opioids (limited use).
  • Non-Pharmacologic Management:
    • Identify and avoid triggers.
    • Regulated lifestyle: Healthy diet, regular exercise, consistent sleep, stress management (e.g., yoga, meditation).
    • Neuromodulation techniques: sTMS, nVNS.
  • Key Recommendations:
    • Use medications early in an attack.
    • If symptoms persist after 60 minutes, consider increasing the initial dose or switching drug classes.
    • Individualize treatment based on attack severity and patient response.
  • Indications for Preventive Treatment:
    • Consider for patients with four or more migraine attacks per month or those unresponsive to abortive treatments.
  • Pharmacologic Options:
    • Beta Blockers: Propranolol, metoprolol.
    • Antidepressants: Amitriptyline, nortriptyline, venlafaxine.
    • Anticonvulsants: Topiramate, valproate.
    • CGRP Antagonists: Eptinezumab, erenumab, fremanezumab, galcanezumab.
    • Other Medications: Flunarizine, candesartan, melatonin.
  • Considerations:
    • Preventive treatments often take 2–12 weeks to show effect.
    • Side effects vary; some medications require careful monitoring (e.g., weight gain with certain antidepressants).
    • Neuromodulation (sTMS) is also FDA-approved for prevention.
  • Patient Management:
    • Start with low doses and gradually increase.
    • Monitor effectiveness and side effects.
    • After stabilization, taper off medication after approximately six months to assess ongoing need.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents with sudden onset headache and right-sided weakness. He has a history of cocaine use. Which of the most likely mechanism caused his intracerebral hemorrhage?

A 40-year-old woman presents with a headache that has become increasingly frequent over the past month. She mentions that she often takes over-the-counter pain relievers to alleviate her discomfort. During the visit, she described her headaches as dull and pressing, primarily located around her forehead, and she rarely experiences nausea or light sensitivity. Which of the following types of headaches is NOT classified as a primary headache?
questions.explanation:
Primary Headaches

Secondary Headaches
  • Migraine (with or without aura) (Option C ruled out)
  • Tension-type headache- Most common (Option A ruled out)
  • Trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia (cluster) (Option D ruled out)
  • Primary stabbing headache
  • Primary coughing headache
  • Primary exertional headache
  • Sex-related headache
  • Thunderclap headache
  • New daily persistent headache syndrome
  • Medication overuse headache (chronic daily headache)
  • Intracranial bleeding (subdural haematoma, subarachnoid or intracerebral haemorrhage)
  • Raised intracranial pressure (brain tumour, idiopathic intracranial hypertension)
  • Infection (meningitis, encephalitis, brain abscess)
  • Inflammatory disease (temporal arteritis, other vasculitis, arthritis)
  • Referred pain from other structures (orbit, temporomandibular joint, neck)

questions.text: A newborn delivered by forceps has a high-pitched cry and bulging anterior fontanelle. The mother notes that the baby seems unusually irritable. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial diagnostic step and management?
questions.explanation:
Intraventricular Hemorrhage in Neonates

Key Risk Factors

- Prematurity (≤32 weeks)

- Low birth weight (<1500g)

- No antenatal steroids

- Vaginal delivery

Clinical Features

- Bulging fontanelle

- Apnea/lethargy

- Seizures

- Often asymptomatic

Diagnosis

- Head USG (primary tool)

- MRI for complications

Management

- Minimal handling

- Maintain stable BP

- Monitor for hydrocephalus

- Phenobarbital for convulsion prevention

questions.text: A 75-year-old man with atrial fibrillation on warfarin presents with progressive confusion and unsteady gait over the past month. His wife reports he had a minor fall 6 weeks ago. On examination, he is confused, has mild left-sided weakness, and his gait is shuffling. CT brain of the patient is given below. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiological mechanism of this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Direct arterial bleeding with rapid expansion

options.label: B
options.text: Recurrent microbleeds with inflammatory response and osmotic fluid accumulation

options.label: C
options.text: Subarachnoid space hemorrhage with CSF mixing

options.label: D
options.text: Primary brain parenchymal bleeding with edema

questions.correct_answer: B. Recurrent microbleeds with inflammatory response and osmotic fluid accumulation
questions.explanation:
Feature

Acute SDH

Chronic SDH

Timing

0-72 hours

>3 weeks

Clinical Features

- Rapid deterioration

- Loss of consciousness

- Focal deficits

- High mortality

- Gradual onset

- Confusion

- Headache

- Gait disturbance

- Better prognosis

Risk Factors

- Severe trauma

- Young adults

- Coagulopathy

- Elderly

- Brain atrophy

- Anticoagulation

- Minor trauma

CT Findings

- Hyperdense crescent

- Immediate mass effect

- Hypodense/mixed density

- Bilateral in 20-30%

- Gradual mass effect

Management

- Emergency craniotomy

- Reverse coagulopathy

- ICU care

- Burr hole drainage

- Hold anticoagulation

- May observe small ones

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the emergency department after being struck in the temporal region during a hockey game. Initially conscious at the scene, he now presents with decreasing consciousness, right-sided pupillary dilation, and left hemiparesis. CT head shows a lentiform hyperdense lesion in the right temporal region with 12mm midline shift. What is the most appropriate immediate management?

options.label: C
options.text: Emergency burr hole followed by craniotomy

questions.correct_answer: C. Emergency burr hole followed by craniotomy

questions.text: A 75-year-old man on warfarin (INR 2.5) falls and hits his head. He is initially alert and oriented, but after 2 hours, becomes progressively drowsy and confused. His CT scan is given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Type

Lucid Interval

CT Findings

Mechanism

Epidural Hematoma

++

- Biconvex/lentiform shape

- Does not cross suture lines

- Cross dural venous sinuses

- Hyperdense

- Usually unilateral

-Typically meningeal artery injury (especially middle meningeal)

-High velocity trauma

-Young patient

-Always traumatic

Subdural Hematoma (Option B)

+/-

- Crescent-shaped

- Crosses suture lines

- Can be bilateral

- Don't cross dural venous sinuses

- Follows brain surface

- Bridging vein tears

- Can be Traumatic or non traumatic

- Elderly patients

- Extent of brain injury more in SDH than EDH

Intraparenchymal Hematoma (Option C)

Absent

- Irregular shape within brain tissue

- May have surrounding edema

Direct tissue damage or coagulopathy

Subarachnoid Haemorrhage       (Option D)

Absent

- Blood in sulci/cisterns

- Follows CSF spaces

Trauma or aneurysm rupture

questions.text: A 72-year-old man on warfarin for atrial fibrillation presents to the emergency department with sudden onset headache, right-sided weakness, and altered mental status. His INR is 4.8. CT Brain of the patient is given below. Which of the following represents the most appropriate immediate management strategy?

options.label: D
options.text: 4-factor Prothrombin Complex Concentrate (PCC), Vitamin K 10mg IV, and consider tranexamic acid

questions.correct_answer: D. 4-factor Prothrombin Complex Concentrate (PCC), Vitamin K 10mg IV, and consider tranexamic acid
questions.explanation:
Warfarin associated Intracranial Hemorrhage- Management

First-line Treatment

4-factor PCC

- Rapid INR reversal

- Contains factors II, VII, IX, X

- Faster than FFP

- Lower volume load

Second Component

Vitamin K 10mg IV

- Sustains reversal

- Prevents rebound coagulopathy

- Takes hours for full effect

Additional Treatment

Tranexamic acid

- Antifibrinolytic

- May help stabilize hemorrhage

Alternative if PCC unavailable

FFP (15-30 mL/kg)

- Restores clotting factors to 30-50%

- Requires larger volumes

- Slower to administer

questions.text: A 50-year-old hypertensive man suddenly develops left facial droop and right arm weakness during a meeting. His BP is 220/130 mmHg. CT shows putaminal hemorrhage. What is the MOST appropriate immediate management?

A 65-year-old hypertensive male presents with sudden onset weakness of right face and arm, along with difficulty speaking. He is unable to form words properly but appears to understand commands. Brain imaging shows an acute infarct. Which division of the MCA is most likely involved?
questions.correct_answer: A. Superior division of left MCA

questions.text: An 82-year-old normotensive, non-diabetic man presents with sudden onset confusion and headache. MRI shows multiple lobar hemorrhages. Which is the MOST likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Cerebral Amyloid Angiopathy (CAA)    (Option A)

Berry Aneurysm Rupture   (Option B ruled out)

Hypertensive Crisis     (Option C ruled out)

Venous Sinus Thrombosis (Option D ruled out)

Age Group

Elderly (>60 years)

Younger

Older, with chronic HTN

Younger, hypercoagulable states

Hypertension

None

None

Chronic HTN

None

Hemorrhage Type

Multiple lobar hemorrhages

Subarachnoid, single event

Deep (e.g., putamen, thalamus)

Hemorrhagic infarction

Hemorrhage Location

Cortical-subcortical regions

Subarachnoid space

Deep brain structures

Venous infarction

Imaging

Lobar hemorrhages, microbleeds

Single, subarachnoid bleed

Deep hemorrhage

Venous infarction pattern

Symptoms

Acute neurological symptoms

Thunderclap headache

Often no symptoms

Seizures, focal deficits

Onset

Acute neurological presentation

Sudden, thunderclap headache

Acute, with chronic HTN

Acute, gradual progression

Distribution

Spares deep structures

Focal

Deep brain

Venous infarction
